column2: By their united efforts, each standing on one of the springs of the trap, they pressed them down sufficiently to insert across the jaws a billet which they dragged from a faggot near at hand; and it was then possible to extract the silk mouthful from the monster's bite, creased and pierced with many holes, but not torn.

column2: Fitzpiers assisted her to put it on again; and when her customary contours were thus restored they walked on together, Grace taking his arm, till he effected an improvement by clasping it round her waist.
column3: Fitzpiers assisted her to put it on again; and when her customary contours were thus restored they walked on together, Grace taking his arm, till he effected an improvement by clasping it round her waist.

column2: The ice having been broken in this unexpected manner, she made no further attempt at reserve.
column3: The ice having been broken in this unexpected manner, she made no further attempt at reserve.

column2: I would ask you to come into the house, she said, "but my meetings with you have been kept secret from my father, and I should like to prepare him."
column3: I would ask you to come into the house, she said, "but my meetings with you have been kept secret from my father, and I should like to prepare him."

column2: Never mind, dearest.	Never mind, dearest.

column2: I could not very well have accepted the invitation.

column2: I shall never live here again--as much for your sake as for mine.
column3: I shall never live here again-as much for your sake as for mine.

column2: I have news to tell you on this very point, but my alarm had put it out of my head.
column3: I have news to tell you on this very point, but my alarm had put it out of my head.

column2: I have bought a practice, or rather a partnership, in the Midlands, and I must go there in a week to take up permanent residence.
column3: I have bought a practice, or rather a partnership, in the Midlands, and I must go there in a week to take up permanent residence.

column2: My poor old great-aunt died about eight months ago, and left me enough to do this.
column3: My poor old great aunt died about eight months ago, and left me enough to do this.

column2: I have taken a little furnished house for a time, till we can get one of our own."
column3: I have taken a little furnished house for a time, till we can get one of our own."

column2: He described the place, and the surroundings, and the view from the windows, and Grace became much interested.
column3: He described the place, and the surroundings, and the view from the windows, and Grace became much interested.

column2: But why are you not there now? she said.
column3: But why are you not there now? she said.

column2: Because I cannot tear myself away from here till I have your promise. Now, darling, you will accompany me there--will you not?	Because I cannot tear myself away from here till I have your promise. Now, darling, you will accompany me there-will you not?
column3: true

column2: To-night has settled that."
column3: To night has settled that."

column2: Grace's tremblings had gone off, and she did not say nay.
column3: Grace's tremblings had gone off, and she did not say nay.

column2: They went on together.
column3: They went on together.

column2: The adventure, and the emotions consequent upon the reunion which that event had forced on, combined to render Grace oblivious of the direction of their desultory ramble, till she noticed they were in an encircled glade in the densest part of the wood, whereon the moon, that had imperceptibly added its rays to the scene, shone almost vertically. It was an exceptionally soft, balmy evening for the time of year, which was just that transient period in the May month when beech-trees have suddenly unfolded large limp young leaves of the softness of butterflies' wings.

It was an exceptionally soft, balmy evening for the time of year, which was just that transient period in the May month when beech trees have suddenly unfolded large limp young leaves of the softness of butterflies' wings.

column2: Boughs bearing such leaves hung low around, and completely enclosed them, so that it was as if they were in a great green vase, which had moss for its bottom and leaf sides.
column3: Boughs bearing such leaves hung low around, and completely enclosed them, so that it was as if they were in a great green vase, which had moss for its bottom and leaf sides.

column2: The clouds having been packed in the west that evening so as to retain the departing glare a long while, the hour had seemed much earlier than it was.

column2: But suddenly the question of time occurred to her.

column2: By the gods, I think I have lost my train! said Fitzpiers.

column2: Dear me--whereabouts are we? said she.

column2: I'll tell my father that we have made it up.

column2: But, as I must stay at the Earl of Wessex to-night, for I cannot possibly catch the train, I think it would be safer for you to let me take care of you.
